pageContext.claim: “And the way they had it, they spent a fortune. But they knew something was wrong, because they went to Gucci, right? And they were in the river at the convention center. And they had a big display of, uh, fourth of July, the... Whatever the hell it is, right? The fireworks. And they paid a lot of money. But now they had to pay $7 million. They owed $7 million to Gucci, and they, uh, were all set to do it. And then they decided to cancel. So, I then called up Gucci. I said, "Listen, it's way far away from my location, but I'll give you a million dollars, okay? I tried to buy their fireworks. I figured I'd give New York it. Have a little fun.”
pageContext.analysis: The Hillary Clinton campaign had arranged to shoot off fireworks over the Hudson for two minutes as early as 9:30 p.m on Election Night, but canceled the event the week before. There is no sign Clinton owed money to Gucci and the $7-million price tag seems way too high. In 2020, the cash-strapped Trump campaign paid $500,000 to Gucci to light fireworks over the Washington monument when Trump accepted the GOP nomination.
